Pre-Game Insights: India would be keen not to repeat the mistakes of their last encounter with England, where they were thrashed by 10 wickets.
In the absence of Jasprit Bumrah, the bowlers lacked the firepower to challenge England in the previous T20 World Cup semi-final.
India have struggled in the big knockout games in ICC events in the last decade, often falling in semis and finals.
England were beaten by Australia but seem to have regained their mojo as they prevailed in a tough group in the Super 8s.
Shivam Dube made 28 from 22 balls but is yet to justify his place ahead of players like Sanju Samson and Yashasvi Jaiswal.
Among the bowlers, Ravindra Jadeja's form with the ball is a big worry. He has picked up just one wicket so far and hasn't done much with the bat too.
Kuldeep Yadav has been the standout spinner for India in the Super 8s, taking seven wickets in three games at an economy rate of 6.25.
England's openers Jos Buttler and Philip Salt are capable of destroying any bowling attack in the Powerplay.
The Indian spin trio of Kuldeep, Jadeja and Axar Patel will have their task cut against the trio of Jonny Bairstow, Moeen Ali and Harry Brook.
England's most dangerous batter in the death overs is Liam Livingstone, who boasts of a strike rate of 151 in T20 Internationals.
A fit-again Jofra Archer will be a big threat with the ball, he has been in good form in this World Cup with nine wickets at an economy rate of just over seven.
